slides.title: Goal and Strategy
items: Goal: derive a nuisance for MiNNLO Z (5FS, massless b quarks) using a comparison to Zbb MiNNLO (4FS, massive b quarks).
Core method: compare distributions between the two samples and interpret differences as candidate nuisance content.
Important context: 5FS vs 4FS scheme differences are part of the physical effect entering this nuisance.

slides.title: Samples and Object Definitions
items: Nominal sample: inclusive Zmumu MiNNLO (5FS, massless b).
Alternate sample: Zbb MiNNLO (4FS, massive b). (Note: it seems this sample is actually $Z \to ee$.)
Objects shown in this draft: LHE bb observables, gen b-jet observables, and B-hadron observables from GenPart-based definitions in the histmaker.

slides.title: LHE Composition
slides.selection_note_latex: Counts are built from LHEPart with b quarks identified by $|\mathrm{pdgId}|=5$ and split by status: initial-state has status $=-1$, final-state has status $=1$.

slides.title: LHE Kinematics
slides.selection_note_latex: $m_{bb}^{\mathrm{LHE}}$ and $\Delta R_{bb}^{\mathrm{LHE}}$ are computed from LHE $b$ and $\bar b$ quarks with $|\mathrm{pdgId}|=5$; $p_{T}$ observables use final-state LHE $b$ quarks with status $=1$.
slides.conclusion_note_latex: Swapping at LHE-quark level is unphysical here because the two samples differ by flavor scheme (5FS vs 4FS), not just by a small kinematic perturbation.

slides.title: LHE b-Quark pT Spectra
slides.selection_note_latex: Final-state LHE $b$ quarks are selected with status $=1$ and $|\mathrm{pdgId}|=5$; shown are event-wise minimum and maximum $p_{T}$ across final-state $b/\bar b$ quarks.

slides.title: Jet-Level Composition and pT
slides.selection_note_latex: A gen $b$-jet is defined by $\mathrm{hadronFlavour}=5$; $n_{\mathrm{bjets}}$ uses $p_{T}>20\,\mathrm{GeV}$ and $|\eta|<2.5$, while the leading-jet $p_{T}$ panel uses the loose ordered list with $p_{T}>0$ and $|\eta|<10$ (as stored in NanoAOD).
slides.conclusion_note_latex: Because gen jets in NanoAOD effectively have a threshold near $20\,\mathrm{GeV}$, many events in the Zbb sample still have no tagged $b$-jets, so this is not a robust swap handle.

slides.title: Jet-Level bb Pair Kinematics
slides.selection_note_latex: $m_{bb}^{\mathrm{jet}}$ and $\Delta R_{bb}^{\mathrm{jet}}$ are computed from the leading two gen $b$-jets after requiring $p_{T}>20\,\mathrm{GeV}$ and $|\eta|<2.5$.
slides.conclusion_note_latex: The ratios are relatively flat between the two samples in these jet-pair observables.

slides.title: B-hadron Multiplicity and pT
slides.selection_note_latex: $B$ hadrons are selected from final-state GenPart objects using the $B$-hadron identifier; multiplicity and $p_{T}$ observables on this slide require hadron $p_{T}>5\,\mathrm{GeV}$.
slides.conclusion_note_latex: Ratios are fairly flat in shape, but there is a sizeable normalization difference; unnormalized swapping would induce an overly large systematic, so a normalized-swap option is motivated.

slides.title: B-hadron Pair Kinematics
slides.selection_note_latex: This slide is restricted to events with at least two $B$ hadrons above $5\,\mathrm{GeV}$; pair observables use the leading two selected $B$ hadrons.

slides.title: Swap Procedure on $p_{T}^{V,\mathrm{gen}}$ (Unnormalized)
slides.selection_note_latex: Procedure: select events with at least two $B$ hadrons above $5\,\mathrm{GeV}$ and subleading $B$-hadron $p_T>10\,\mathrm{GeV}$ in both samples; replace the selected 5FS component with the selected 4FS component without extra scaling.
slides.conclusion_note_latex: Conclusion: this direct swap induces a too-large systematic because of the normalization difference.

slides.title: Swap Procedure on $p_{T}^{V,\mathrm{gen}}$ (Normalized)
slides.selection_note_latex: Procedure: same event selection as previous slide, but normalize the selected 4FS component to the selected 5FS yield before replacement.
slides.conclusion_note_latex: With normalization, the ratio is much flatter and the effect is more shape-like, making this prescription more suitable as a nuisance candidate, though it may be unphysical.

slides.title: Backup: Parton-Flavour Jet Multiplicity and Leading $p_T$
slides.selection_note_latex: Backup check: define jet tags with parton flavour ($|\mathrm{partonFlavour}|=5$) and use the same jet kinematic cuts as in the hadron-flavour study.
slides.conclusion_note_latex: These parton-flavour-tagged shapes are qualitatively very similar to the hadron-flavour-tagged ones.

slides.title: Backup: Parton-Flavour Jet Pair Kinematics
slides.selection_note_latex: Backup check: compare $m_{bb}^{\mathrm{jet}}$ and $\Delta R_{bb}^{\mathrm{jet}}$ built from parton-flavour-tagged jets.
slides.conclusion_note_latex: Again, behavior is close to the hadron-flavour case, so this does not materially change the swap-handle conclusion.
